Note: although this was a review for birkholz-02, I don't think the points raised have been addressed in birkholz-03 (which I guess it's equivalent to rats-00).

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Can this be closed now?

comments.author: thomas-fossati

issues.title: Add CDDL
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
UCCS-message = UCCS-tagged-message / UCCS-untagged-message

UCCS-tagged-message = #6.601(cwt-claims-set)

UCCS-untagged-message = cwt-claims-set

Then where is cwt-claims-set defined? Seems like it would be OK to define it in the UCCS draft. Right now I define eat-claims-set in EAT and that includes some of the CWT claims. However, I'm OK for all that to move to UCCS. EAT needs a normative reference to UCCS anyway and it would be better to avoid a circular reference between EAT and UCCS.


https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/issues/130

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: Is there something equivalent to cwt-claims-set defined for the payload of a CWT? Logically, a CWT is a 'signed-cwt-payload'. The unsigned part has to be recognizable as CBOR, so wouldn't that be the same as UCCS-untagged-message?

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
There is no CDDL definition of the payload of a CWT anywhere, no definition of cwt-claims-set anywhere.  It would be the same as UCCS-untagged-message which is why I thought it might be good to put it here.

It should also have a $$ CDDL socket that additional claims can be defined. EAT, for example woulds use the $$ CDDL socket for all it's claims.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: [edited] Claims Sets are defined in RFC7519 and inherited by RFC8392. These Claims Sets are the basis for CWT and thereby are the "payload of a CWT". This might be just me, but I am drawing a blank here. Could you please provide a (preliminary) change proposal so that we can look at a potential solution to a problem statement that is hard for me to follow? At the moment, I am inclined to assume that this is an obvious non-issue - but again that might be me, not getting the problem.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
Henk, they are defined in *prose*, but there is no accompanying CDDL as is becoming the convention for CBOR-based protocols.  There is no desire to redefine any semantics, just to add some CDDL that parallels what the prose says.

My immediate problem in EAT is that there's no CDDL to reference when a claim-set is to be used, not can I produce the top-level CDDL for EAT. To address this, I've constructed my own CDDL for a CWT and it is in EAT. That is tolerable, but it seems like it would be more general to have this in the more general UCCS.

Another problem is that there's no $$ socket to add claims to a CWT. All new CWT claims should probably be defined in CDDL. While a $$ socket is not required to define new claims in CDDL, it is helpful, particularly with the next.

A third problem is that EAT and other protocols (some of which are probably yours) are doing automated verification of the CDDL definition in the RFC against the examples in the RFC and more. If there's no CDDL, that can't be done.

My plan is to write up the cleanest CDDL I can that I think should go into UCCS. There's a less-clean version of it in EAT right now.  Then we can decide if it goes in EAT or more generally goes into UCCS.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
Then let us define a CDDL specification in EAT instead of trying to use CDDL fragments as an information model, I'd say. I am rather certain that I brought this up before, but a few years ago that did not seem to be a viable route. If that has changed, we can create a feasible way forward - in the scope of EAT. Touching JWT and CWT to that seems a bit blown out of proportions, I think.

JWT and CWT are anchored in independent RFCs. If there would be enough support for reopening that work.. well I'd not be blocking that, but I'd also not be an advocate for that. I think I understand now, where you are coming from. But what you illustrate here as your target goes way beyond EAT. Maybe finishing EAT first should be the priority and then we can take the lessons learned and bring other folks in to talk about "Serialization Agnostics Claims Sets" and how these can be reused in JSON and/or CBOR?

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
I'm having a hard time following this discussion.

I think it is good to have CDDL for CWT (don't care about JWT).

I think it would be good to do this in a way that the act of registering new claims can be accompanied by adding simple CDDL for these claims.  So a including a socket seems like the right way to do this.

I don't think defining this CDDL warrants a CWTbis.  Writing a document specifically for this sounds a bit thin, but could be done (and would clearly be in the COSE WG). Attaching this to the UCCS document also works, certainly better than attaching it to some random CWT-using document (UCCS is "infrastructure" for CWT, EAT is not).

I'm not a big fan for doing everything with a ton of representation variants, so doing anything of this for JWT as well needs some good motivation (and maybe even resurrection of JOSE).

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: If we leave JWT out of the picture, this could boil down to provide "CWT CDDL" in the UCCS I-D? I can follow that thought. I never really had a problem with the English text definition in CWT, but admittedly most people seem to create "their own" CWT CDDL based on that English text anyways.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
... yes, and having some easy-to-copy CDDL is preferable.

Also a common way to fill the socket.

I'll propose something later today.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: I guess this conversation needs to be resurrected now that https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/pull/176 has landed.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
@laurencelundblade is [this](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/blob/master/cddl/external/uccs.cddl) the CDDL that should appear in UCCS?

PS: ideally, EAT-13 and UCCS-03 should come out at the same time.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Once https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/pull/336 is merged in the EAT document, we can close this issue.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Thanks, Laurence!

issues.title: Unsigned JSON format claims?
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
JWT has this null cipher construct for unsigned JSON claims-sets. It seems wasteful and ill conceived to me especially in light of UCCS.

EAT is successfully defining claims in both JSON and CBOR.

Why not make UCCS in to a CDDL definition of the basic claims in CWT and JWT and define simpler way to do unsigned claims in JSON format?  You already have all the security considerations.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: I believe the spirit of this issue is now covered in the CDDL.  Closing.

issues.title: (editorial): harmonize capitalization
issues.author: cabo
issues.body: (As per Ned Smith's message of November 8, 2022)

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Claim Key as specified in RFC8392 are currently called lables in the CDDL in the Appendix. "Claim Key" by itself is only used in the definition of UCCS and never again. Should we decide on a consistent use of Claim Key or highlight that is a synonym to label before the CDDL in appendix?

issues.title: UCCS and UJCS EARs?
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
Seems like you'd want UCCS or UJCS EARs -- lots of B2B over TLS for attestation results I'd expect.

As written, there's no option for this because CWT/JWT is a requirement.

issues.title: Registration/glue to hook UCCS into EAT
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
I've mentioned this in email; thought it should be here for the record

EAT defines a socket where new token formats plug-in.  This draft should provide the CDDL to hook UCCS into the socket.

Additionally, if UJCS is supported here, a type string for the JSON token selector needs to be defined.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Fixed in #25

issues.title: Support UJCS (or remove/clarify presence of JSON definitions)
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
I've mentioned this in email; thought it should be here also for the record

This is a request to add support for UJCS (unsigned JSON tokens).

If UJCS support is not added, then the JSON definitions should either be removed or their presence explained in prose.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Fixed in #25

issues.title: Missing reference to RFC 9165 for .feature CDDL control operator
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body: Appendix A uses .feature for the JC<> generic. That is defined in RFC 9165, not RFC 8610 so a reference to it is needed.

pulls.title: First attempt at addressing Thomas' review
pulls.author: cabo

pulls.title: CDDL for UCCS (and UJCS) and examples in diag
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body:
I'm sure there'll be lots of comments...

The examples validate against the CDDL using the cddl command line tool.

I can't ignore JSON in EAT, so a claims-set that doesn't work for JSON is mostly useless to me, so this covers JSON.

I didn't include CWT, though EAT needs that too. I looked at the way CoSWID did CWT, but am not sure that would work for EAT.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Closing this as overtaken by events.

pulls.title: Start work on a CDDL appendix
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body: This appendix collects CDDL for CWT and the RFCs defining further claims for that.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I can't see a way to use this in EAT. EAT firmly uses CDDL to specify both CBOR and JSON encodings. The claims-set is the fundamental structure in EAT, so the claims-set has to be CDDL that works for CBOR and JSON. The main problem with this PR is it is hard-coded to integer labels. 

I'm open to lots of suggestions and ideas here, but if this PR is what goes into UCCS, then EAT would have to say "ignore the CDDL in UCCS and use the CDDL for CWT/JWT here in EAT instead".

I also understand that this is probably way beyond what work you expected to do on UCCS. 

I'm really open to a variety of solutions, just can't think of anything else yet.

```suggestion
Another use case is that of a sub-Attester that has no signing keys (for example, to keep the implementation complexity to a minimum) and has a secure channel, such as a local IPC, to interact with a lead Attester (see Composite Device {{Section 3.3 of -rats}}).
The sub-Attester produces a UCCS with the required claims-set and sends the unprotected claims-set through the secure channel to the lead Attester which, in turn, computes a cryptographic hash of the claims-set and protects that hash using its signing key for Evidence, for example, using a Detached EAT Bundle ({{Section 5 of -eat}}).
```

reviews.author: henkbirkholz
reviews.body: due to my suggestions, I approve

comments.body: SPDM connected components over a system bus such as MCTP is another concrete example
Arm CCA attestation in "direct" mode another.
Except if the same key would've been used in both cases -- which seems to be the assumption here?

comments.body:
possibly missing plural

```suggestion
  or other object security than COSE, such as CMS or X.509 v3 certificates.
```

```suggestion
  the COSE protection. Examples include, encrypted conveyance via PCIe, a TLS tunnel,
```

```suggestion
  the COSE protection. Examples include encrypted conveyance via PCIe, a TLS tunnel,
```

```suggestion
When transported over secure channels, CBOR Web Token (CWT, RFC 8392) Claims Sets may not need the protection afforded by wrapping them into COSE, as is required for a true CWT.
```

pulls.title: evidence => any conceptual message
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body: In principle, the usage scope can be extended to any RATS conceptual message.

comments.body: Why is privacy only important for Attester Verifier interactions and not for all CM exchanges?
I'm only aware of privacy preserving attestation schemes involving attester-verifier interactions.

> I'm only aware of privacy preserving attestation schemes involving attester-verifier interactions.

A background-check scenario, the RP may be privy to Evidence redirected by the RP to the Verifier.
Also, a RP may request (of the Verifier) to view the accepted claims rather than or in addition to Attestation Results that somehow obfuscate original claims (that are privacy sensitive).
Auditors may expect access to original claims (that are privacy sensitive) who are not the Verifier (audit trail data may be considered a CM even through it isn't described by RFC9334).
OK, thanks.  How do you want to tweak the current text?
...when a privacy preserving Secure Channel is employed for conveying a conceptual message the receiver cannot correlate the message with the senders of other received UCCS messages...

> ...when a privacy preserving Secure Channel is employed for conveying a conceptual message the receiver cannot correlate the message with the senders of other received UCCS messages...

WFM

reviews.author: quic-jodonogh
reviews.body: Agree on the changes discussed with Ned, and note a couple of nits. Will wait for updated PR to formally approve.

comments.body: Probably "between" rather than "from", or it reads awkwardly.
WFM as well.

```suggestion
Furthermore, the channel MUST provide integrity of the communication between the
```
OK, done in [44fbe5](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-uccs/pull/16/commits/d44fbe53a98ee6c2fe805f18c8b18f5da8694edc)

pulls.title: Generalize to support both JSON and CBOR Claims Sets
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body:
Had to rename the document since it was named only for CBOR/CWT. Chose "UCS" but it could be "UTCS" or other too.

Didn't really have to change semantics of anything

Added and corrected CDDL. Note that even the CDDL for just UCCS was inadequate because it didn't define the tagged and untagged.

Added CDDL to glue into EAT

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
> I can only find one small nit in the technical content, but I don't really like the way that the document now reads in that CWT/JWT, COSE/JOSE and similar appear now all over the document, and as a result, it reads awkwardly.
> 
> I think part of the problem is that there is an important semantic difference between UCCS and UJCS, and that is the fact that UCCS are always tagged - this is an important semantic difference because the intent of the attester is clearly signalled in a way that JSON doesn't allow, and this doesn't come out in the amended text.

You are right that UCCS is always a CBOR tag as specified in the document, but I think that is wrong. It is one of the things I think must be fixed regardless of whether we do UJCS or not. (Use of or not of the CBOR tag is a characteristic of the surrounding protocol and is pretty much always optional).

But more importantly, can you clarify what intent is being signaled in regards to attestation? Is it more than just the identification of the data/message type?

 
> 
> I won't make this a blanket "reject" if the other editors are OK, but it just doesn't "feel" quite right to me.

I can see how the text is not ideal but from my point of view, it's tolerable, gets the job done and avoids me (and others) having to do the work for a whole separate document. Maybe you would do the same if you were me? :-)

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: This addresses issues #20, #21, #22

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: FYI, I'm planning to rework this in a very different way after discussion with Thomas, Henk and Cabo at the hackathon.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Thank you all for commenting on the way; this will be reworked.

_"a CBOR and JSON"_ seems too vague.

I guess there's more than one thing that is defined here:
* a CBOR tag for UCCS
* the CDDL for the claims-set
* the glue CDDL to plug UCS into EAT

If the WG really is interested in extending the scope of this document, the building blocks Thomas illustrated must be reflected in a corresponding document structure.

Some "catch-all" changes now include assertions that might not be backed by implementations. For example:

> The sub-Attester produces a UCS with the required Claims Set and sends the UCS through the Secure Channel to the lead Attester.

While in theory that might be possible, as an individual I have no knowledge of any activity that does generate JSON Evidence or plans to do this. As this is becoming a normative specification, does anybody can point me to such activities?

reviews.author: quic-jodonogh
reviews.body:
I can only find one small nit in the technical content, but I don't really like the way that the document now reads in that CWT/JWT, COSE/JOSE and similar appear now all over the document, and as a result, it reads awkwardly.

I think part of the problem is that there is an important semantic difference between UCCS and UJCS, and that is the fact that UCCS are always tagged - this is an important semantic difference because the intent of the attester is clearly signalled in a way that JSON doesn't allow, and this doesn't come out in the amended text.

I won't make this a blanket "reject" if the other editors are OK, but it just doesn't "feel" quite right to me.

comments.body: I think you would need to write something about JWT here.

Normally we expect RFCs to have implementations behind them. Are there implementations for UCCS and UJCS? (I'm not expecting this PR to resolve the question, but asking since if there aren't implementations then that could be a factor if the PR is trying to focus on capabilities that are new to the original effort).
ctoken/xclaim implements UCCS. It has a very basic implementation of UJCS encoding, but no implementation of UJCS decoding.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
UCCS = #6.601(Claims-Set)
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
UJCS = Claims-Set
```

pulls.title: EAT and JSON support
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body: I haven't validated the CDDL here yet, nor the change to the EAT JSON selector. Not expecting a problem but probably should be done before final merges.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
I think that @quic-jodonogh wanted to get rid of the generic definition here

```
JSON-ONLY<J> = J .feature "json"
CBOR-ONLY<C> = C .feature "cbor"
JC<J,C> = JSON-ONLY<J> / CBOR-ONLY<C>
```

and would have preferred two independent appendices? I might have gotten that wrong. Any comments on this?

comments.author: quic-jodonogh
comments.body:
> I think that @quic-jodonogh wanted to get rid of the generic definition here
> 
> ```
> JSON-ONLY<J> = J .feature "json"
> CBOR-ONLY<C> = C .feature "cbor"
> JC<J,C> = JSON-ONLY<J> / CBOR-ONLY<C>
> ```
> 
> and would have preferred two independent appendices? I might have gotten that wrong. Any comments on this?

That is what we discussed and (I believe) agreed during the meeting: that UCCS would remain CBOR only with an informative appendix that says something like:

- here is an example of how you could use UCCS with JSON.

Should also note that the CDDL remains generic. This is probably OK provided that there is text that says something like *This specification only provides normative definitions of UCCS with CBOR*, so that it is clear that the *J* branch in a *`<J,C>`* is not being defined normatively.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
On Nov 9, 2023, at 13:57, Henk Birkholz ***@***.***> wrote:
> 
> JSON-ONLY<J> = J .feature "json"
> CBOR-ONLY<C> = C .feature "cbor"
> JC<J,C> = JSON-ONLY<J> / CBOR-ONLY<C>

I think we can leave in this “switch” without the JSON part becoming normative.

Grüße, Carsten

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I definitely prefer retaining JC<>

- it seems to be the current practice for combined JSON and CBOR
- it keeps the appendix in EAT, which we can't really change, in line with this draft
- it generally keeps alignment in methodology for JSON + CBOR definitions for all of JWT and CWT

If we do this in a different way here, it will set a counter-precedent for Claims-Sets in CDDL.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
This would be easier to review if we already had the version of EAT into which these changes go.
I.e., merge https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/pull/431 and publish a -23.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
Agreed that UCCS and UJCS are claims-sets, not tokens so the latest update fully commits to that.
However, they do become tokens in EAT so the EAT section refers to them so.

Also fixed the missing the tagged and untagged CDDL definitions for UCCS.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: This fixes #20, #21 and #22

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Good for 2nd round of "2 week WGLC" :raised_hands:

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: Thanks Laurence, LGTM!  A couple of editorial suggestions inline.

comments.body:
```suggestion
The definition for a UJCS token in CDDL is identical to that of a Claims-Set.
```

```suggestion
This can be referred to as a "UJCS", an Unprotected JWT Claims Set".
```

This doesn't read super smoothly :-)

What about:

```suggestion
The following CDDL adds UCCS and UJCS tokens to EAT using the predefined extension points.
```

```suggestion
Such an unsigned token can be referred to as a "UJCS", an "Unprotected JWT Claims Set".
```

```suggestion
The CDDL definition in the appendix above works for JSON as well as CBOR through the use of the JC<> CDDL generic.
```
I am having a some difficulties parsing that sentence.

```suggestion
The following CDDL definition adds types for UCCS and UJCS to EAT using its predefined extension points.
```

I'm not sure what the issue is with parsing here.

_"A UJCS token is a Claims-Set with JSON encoding"_ would sound better?

Neither UCCS nore "UJCS" are token?

Maybe: The CDDL definition in Figure 1 can be used for "UJCS".

> Neither UCCS nore "UJCS" are token?

ok, now I can parse your parsing error :-)

> Maybe: The CDDL definition in Figure 1 can be used for "UJCS".

yeah, why not.

Indeed, UCCS and UJCS are not tokens.
Can we say "its predefined"  (to make clear that it is EAT that predefines these)?

```suggestion
The CDDL definition in Figure FIXME can be used for "UJCS".
```

This CDDL definition (fragment) has no Figure label, so I used "FIXME" in the suggestion above.
~~~ cddl
UJCS-Token = Claims-Set
~~~
incorporated in the suggestion above

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body:
LGTM, thanks!

@laurencelundblade: could you please add a note of the open issues addressed by this PR (i.e., "Fixes #20, #21 and #22") so that the scope is clear and the issues can be automatically closed on merge?

comments.body: This probably needs references, expansion, etc.
Add reference to EAT submods section. That's what you are after, right?

The reference looks good to me ([this para](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-rats-eat-22#section-4.2.18-15) of §4.2.18, specifically).

I don't think EAT needs to be expanded here, it's already mentioned in §4.1, §4.2 and §4.3.  More likely, when first introduced.

reviews.author: cabo
reviews.body:
Indeed, this now looks good to me.

(The »(submods)« isn't quite literally the section name, but the RFC editor can fix that.)

comments.body:
LGTM

@cabo confirmed

pulls.title: Provide narrative for the ;# import directive.
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body:
We do *not* want to restate the below from RFC 9052.

Addressing
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/iQ32uScNs2lcsAm9WJltbYJb894/

``` 
COSE_Key = {
  1 => tstr / int,
  ? 2 => bstr,
  ? 3 => tstr / int,
  ? 4 => [+ tstr / int],
  ? 5 => bstr,
  * label => values, }
COSE_Encrypt = [
  Headers,
  ciphertext: bstr / nil,
  recipients: [+ COSE_recipient],
]
COSE_Encrypt0 = [
  Headers,
  ciphertext: bstr / nil,
]
label = int / tstr
values = any
Headers = (
  protected: empty_or_serialized_map,
  unprotected: header_map,
  )
COSE_recipient = [
  Headers,
  ciphertext: bstr / nil,
  ? recipients: [+ COSE_recipient],
]
empty_or_serialized_map = bstr .cbor header_map / bstr .size 0 header_map = {
  Generic_Headers,
  * label => values, }
Generic_Headers = (
  ? 1 => int / tstr,
  ? 2 => [+ label],
  ? 3 => tstr / int,
  ? 4 => bstr,
  ? (5 => bstr // 6 => bstr),
  )
```
